ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about writing about architecture from an architecture critic's perspective. I learned about the process of how writers create columns that would go in an architectural news source.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: writing assignments, readings, instructor feedback
Weakness: sometimes not as much discussion in class as I would've liked

I enjoyed doing architectural tours for various buildings around Yale's Campus and going to New York City to tour some of the more critically acclaimed sights. The readings were also interesting. The sketches also gave me a great opportunity to view campus from a new perspective.

Strengths: The reading list is great, and the walking tours were amazing. I think the assignments were the best part of the course; the prompts were engaging and were unlike anything I had to do for other classes. I particularly liked writing about Yale buildings, as we could interact with the world around us. 
Weaknesses: there was barely any discussion during class time which made class less engaging than in could've been. I think it could be improved by having more guidance in terms of what we should be discussing each class period.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I came into this course with little background in writing or architecture and really enjoyed it. The writing assignments are fun and helpful, and I enjoyed many of the readings. The instructor provides a ton of really helpful feedback on your writing, which I thought was incredibly valuable. Writing is also a nice lens through which one can develop one's understanding of architecture, and I felt that I gained an architectural "voice" by the end of the semester.
If they want to learn more about architecture criticism and are interested in becoming a journalist then yes
Yes! If you are interested in learning about architecture in a small group setting.
